title: Old-Fashioned Jelly Roll
full_text:
Old-Fashioned Jelly Roll
Close
Jump to recipe
Prep
25 mins
Cook
30 mins
Active
About 30 mins
Total
55 mins
Serves
12
to 16 servings
Cook Mode
(Keep screen awake)
Ingredients
For the Cake:
4
large
eggs
, straight from the fridge (about
7
ounces
;
200
g
)
7
ounces
plain
or
toasted
sugar
(about
1
cup
;
200
g
)
3/4
teaspoon
baking powder
1/2
teaspoon
(
2
g
) Diamond Crystal
kosher salt
; for
table salt
, use about half as much by volume or the same weight
1/4
teaspoon
baking soda
3
ounces
pistachio oil
,
roasted hazelnut oil
,
melted ghee
(shy
1/2

;
85
g
), or
melted butter
(about
6

;
85
g
)

(about
1

;

)

, such as Gold Medal blue label (about
1

127

)
For the Filling:
1/2
recipe
(about
2

;
21

;
595

)

, brought to room temperature; volume and weight for an alternative will vary substantially (see notes)
For the Frosting (optional):
1/2

12

(about
1 3/4
cup

)

1

Directions
Getting Ready:
Adjust oven rack to lower-middle position and preheat to 350°F (180°C). Line an aluminum half-sheet pan with parchment along the bottom, and grease with pan spray or oil.
For the Cake:
In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, combine the eggs, sugar, baking powder, salt, and baking soda. Mix on medium-low speed until the sugar has dissolved and the mixture is homogeneous, smooth, and runny, but with fine bubbles beginning to form throughout, about 3 minutes.
Increase speed to medium and whip until the mixture is pale yellow, thick enough to fall from the whisk in ribbons, and filled with fine, foamy bubbles, about 5 minutes. Finally, increase speed to high, and continue whipping until the mixture is quite pale, roughly double in volume, and thick enough that the whisk leaves a vortex-like pattern in its wake, about 5 minutes. When allowed to run off the whisk and into the bowl, the mixture should be able to briefly mound up on itself before leveling off. Please bear in mind all times are ballpark figures only, and may vary considerably depending on the power and capacity of a given stand mixer, along with factors such as bowl-to-beater clearance (
more on that here
). In all cases, the visual and textural cues should be the primary guideline to determine readiness.
Serious Eats/Vicky Wasik
Once the foamed eggs are fluffy and thick, reduce speed to medium-high and add the vanilla and oil or melted butter all at once in a steady stream. Immediately reduce speed to medium-low, and add the sifted flour all at once. When the flour is nearly incorporated, shut off the mixer and remove the whisk attachment. Grasping the attachment by its top, give the batter a few strokes of the whisk by hand to finish incorporating the flour. Fold the batter once or twice from the bottom up with a flexible spatula, then scrape into the prepared pan and spread into an even layer with an offset spatula. Bake until puffed and lightly browned from edge to center, and firm to the touch but still puffy and soft enough to retain a shallow impression when gently poked, about 12 minutes.
Serious Eats/Vicky Wasik
Immediately after removing the cake from the oven, cover the half-sheet pan with two large strips of foil, using a kitchen towel or oven mitt to crimp the foil around the edges of the pan. Allow the cake to cool until approximately 70°F (21°C) (if not allowed to cool sufficiently, it may cause the filling to melt; if cooled too much, it may harden in the cold and thus crack when rolled).
Serious Eats/Vicky Wasik
Loosen the edges of the cooled cake from the pan with a butter knife, and give the cranberry jam a good stir before spreading it into an even layer over the cake. Please see the note about using other jams or jellies, as the exact amount (in terms of both weight and volume) will differ substantially depending on the consistency and moisture content. Working along the widest end, lift the edge of the cake by the parchment underneath and gently fold it inward until it turns over itself. Continue rolling, using the parchment to lift and maneuver the cake; it will naturally peel away as you go.
Serious Eats/Vicky Wasik
After rolling, transfer the cake to a large platter and serve right away, or cover with plastic until needed. If you like, make a simple frosting by whipping the apple-cinnamon sugar, cream, and salt together until thick and stiff enough to spread; this can be refrigerated in an airtight container and used to cover the cake just before serving. Alternatively, the cake can be finished with a dusting of powdered sugar. Unfrosted, the cake will keep for about 24 hours at room temperature; if frosted with whipped cream, it will need to be covered, refrigerated for up to 24 hours, and then set out to room temperature about an hour before serving.
Serious Eat/Vicky Wasik
Special Equipment
Stand mixer
,
flexible spatula
,
half-sheet pan
,
offset spatula
Notes
The exact appearance of the jelly roll can vary substantially depending on the texture of the filling. This style of cake tends to work best with thick and chunky jams or marmalades, such as the homemade cranberry jam pictured here. Soft, loose, or runny fillings may be readily absorbed by the cake, creating a scant appearance. Determining the best amount of filling for commercial jams or jelly will require an element of personal discretion; the loose consistency of most commercial options will limit the maximum capacity to about 1 cup (13 ounces, or 370g).
Make-Ahead and Storage
Unfrosted, the cake will keep for about 24 hours at room temperature; if frosted with whipped cream, it will need to be covered, refrigerated for up to 24 hours, and then set out to room temperature about an hour before serving.
